Posts.Content: jenrio wrote: So I had a bit of left chest pressure/pain and breathlessness going on for a few week (5 ish), especially when I'm standing up. It hasn't gone away after my baby's delivery 2 weeks ago, so yesterday I went to ER room for it. They suspected pulmonary embolism but CT didn't find anything. Heart/heart sac is normal, left lung seems ok. But in addition, they found that my heart rate at rest is at 67, but when standing up, it quickly turned into 100. lying down the heart rate went back to 67 again. And I'm not dehydrated. Now it's officially a medical mystery. I'm due for A/C dose 3 tomorrow, but I'm not sure whether I should keep it, due to this weird heart/lung condition. Urgently need advice on this. My onco is out on thanksgiving vacation, I'll need to talk to onduty nurse practitioner about this. Another thing, they found a 4mm nodule in the lower apical peripheral of right lung. They didn't say much, but told me to ask onco to restage me and said it's unlikely to be infection though anybody can have small nodules (etc...). I got the CD, but i haven't had the courage to look. I'm really scared. Jen more details in my blog killerboob.blogspot.com Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Mystery heart problem and lung nodule. Advice urgently needed! jenrio jenrio

Posts.Content: Nov 24, 2011 01:58PM jenrio wrote: After another 2 days running through hospital, I saw a new cardiologist and got an echo.  My LVEF still looks 50%+, so I checked into cancer clinic and got my 3rd dose of AC. Everyone was so nice even the night before thanksgiving, the nurse worked on my chemo and I was one of her last patient.   I'm very thankful for the great support I got from everyone on the board, my friends/family and doctor/nurses.   Happy thanksgiving! BTW, the medical mystery may have a name "POTS syndrome" (an onco college buddy volunteered that theory).   It explains why standing up increases heart rate dramatically (30+ beats)  over lying down.   It's a rare syndrome, but may be underdiagnosed as anxiety or hormonal.   It may actually be due to autoimmune attack on sympathitic nervous system that regulate heart beat.    Often found in late-pregnancy post-partum post-viral infection patients.
Posts.Title: Mystery heart problem and lung nodule. Advice urgently needed! jenrio jenrio

Posts.Content: jenrio wrote: I have an atypical case: I'm diagnosed with stage II IDC, grade III, oncotype=29,ER weakly positive, PR weakly positive, HER2-.    Diagnosis was  3 months ago during pregnancy.   I had lumpectomy and 2 rounds of AC during pregnancy.   Now the baby is delivered safe, I'm going to get imaging studies done.   If I'm still stage II, I'm supposed to keep doing dose dense ACx2 Tx4   My question is: What if MRI shows mets (stage II turns into IV), then will I be moved to hormone therapy instead? What is the rationale for that?   Is Dr trying to save the big gun AC-T for later? Does the location of distant mets matter in this decision?  Bone vs liver vs lung? Sorry to post on this forum.   But the ladies on this board are very knowledgeable about  "diagnosed as stage IV" and "turning into stage IV", so I'm hoping to tap into your collective wisdom. Thanks! more details in my blog killerboob.blogspot.com Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Nov 27, 2011 02:47AM jenrio wrote: Support her and ask her to reconsider.   Check my posts.   I was preggy when diagnosed grade 3 stage 2-3.   Young women need to be open minded and do anything they can to survive for their family.     Before the current treatment, stage 4 BC survival was <5%, stage 3 BC survival was less than 50%.   She should not risk her life like this! Chemo is very tolerable for me so far.   Get her on this board she will get a lot of advice and support.

Posts.Content: Aug 21, 2012 11:25AM jenrio wrote: Sorry this is stage 4 thread.   I remember reading a paper that basically says, for ER+ PR+ patients, the CA27-29 tests are sensitive in about 70+% of patients.   The sensitivity is lower for ER- PR- patients (more like 50%).   I'll post the paper when I find it again. CEA test is less sensitive/specific than CA27-29.   But the 2 tests combined could be more sensitive than either alone.   Then there's also CTC test (cellsearch), which tests for completely different things. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16410341 IMHO, Radiology tests are limited in tracking progression and expensive and potentially harmful.  These serum tests are very useful instead or in addition to radiological test.   Each individual patient should try to find the best tests and understand how your treatment or nontreatment or lifestyle changes impact them and try to optimize your chances.

Posts.Content: May 25, 2012 05:40AM - edited May 25, 2012 05:58AM by jenrio I was dxed during pregnancy and had chemo.   My baby was born beautiful and healthy.   Now I have the time, I want to make a baby calendar.   But it gets old to have only one cute little baby...    So, I'm looking for other women with kids who went through the same thing.  And we can collect all pics and make one nice calendar. If there is demand, I may even start selling this and I want all proceeds-costs to go to a metastatic breast cancer research charity.    The reason is:  well if there is a cure for stage IV, no babies need to go through this again to save their moms' lives. Anyone with me?  Please PM me and send me the highest quality baby pictures you can find.

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2012 08:02PM - edited Feb 2, 2012 08:14PM by jenrio sorry to hear about your progression...     How much is your ER+ and PR+ numbers?   according to my ro,  tamoxifen tends to work for more PR+ women.    What's your cancer's grade?  Also, there's this test:  http://www.nmslab.com/tests/Tamoxifen-and-Metabolites--Serum-Plasma/4311SP  i learned from bco sister seattle85.   however my onco doesn't endorse it. Another way to know whether tam works for you is:  having a PET before and after and compare the SUV of the cancer. Yet another way of maybe guessing:   some people say the worse side effect you have, the better tamoxifen works for you.      Do you see any side effect of tamoxifen? you could always try get ro to radiation your mets...   Best wishes, xoxoxo Jen
Posts.Title: Crap, I knew it. Small Progression. china DivineMrsM

Posts.Content: jenrio wrote: Last november, I had an mammogram and ultrasound of my 2cm mass on my left breast (inner upper quadrant).  It fits the characteristics of fibroadenoma, but mixed echogenecity, which means it's complex.   At the time, the radiologist told me to come back after 6 months to ultrasound again, said it's probably benign. But my primary doc told me to go have biopsy.   I kept twiddling thumbs.  fast forward 3 months, the mass has grown to 3cm.  my primary doc strongly suggested me to go see the breast surgeon. I can't quite figure out what he is worried about, is it because the size doubled/tripled in 3 months?  is this typical growth rate for fibroadenoma or phyllodes?  is he worried about the latter, or something else entirely? So, i  followed my primary doc's advice and went in to see a breast surgeon. he gave me too options, core needle biopsy and excisional biopsy (w/o margin removed).   Either way, if the pathology results are bad, i'll have to do another lumpectomy.   So i asked, can i do a lumpectomy, so biopsy can be more complete and include the surrounding tissue?    The surgeon said no.   he just gave me the two choices. With either kind of biopsy, surgery, earliest date is 12 days away.  I'm a little frustrated, if the primary doc seems so urgent about biopsy, then why does the surgeon seems not in hurry at all?   I kind of prefer to avoid 2 surgeries (excisional biopsy+lumpectomy or core needle biopsy+lumpectomy) as much as possible in the worst case scenario, yet, the surgeon seems very adamant about not cutting the margin off the tumor.  why?  i thought maybe he wasn't sure about how much to cut, and i suggested i want to do MRI, again the answer is no.   MRI is supposed to be able to see phyllodes very well. so maybe they are not worried about phyllodes at all, but some other scenario.    Fundamentally, i can't figure out what they are thinking.   Anyhow, any suggestions?  I'm so glad i found about this forum! more details in my blog killerboob.blogspot.com Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: 3cm mass: fibroadenoma or phyllodes jenrio jenrio

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2010 03:17AM jenrio wrote: Thanks Beesie, you are probably right!   I know phyllodes is low probability.  but i've already hit other low-probability diseases (just not phyllodes yet). I'm also worried because I read from wiki, that 90% of fibroadenoma stops at 3cm, yet mine is already 4cm (i just measured it).    and also, 16%/month growth rate is considered safe for fibroadenoma, but mine's growth rate is already more like 70%/month. I also found this article: emedicine.medscape.com/article...  It seems to emphasize that margin and method of excision as important factors in preventing recurrence of phyllodes.   Also, makes me tend toward asking for wide margin excision to start with.  Phyllodes is notoriously difficult to diagnose from core biopsy anyway.

Posts.Content: Dec 3, 2011 04:33PM jenrio wrote: Congrats for the liver mets' good response to chemo!    I'm not a real confirmed stage IV, but i have good reasons to suspect I am (cancer cells continue to circulate in blood months after lumpectomy/chemo). My understanding is:  mets is a casino game.   the total number of breast cells you have (original breast cells + tumor cells + mets cells) is the total chips that cancer owns.    Since it sounds like you have some inherited condition that makes your "original breast cells" more likely to turn into tumor cells, you might want the the original breast cells out. That said,  major surgery is said by some to stimulate cancer cells into growth.   So, you need to find a good time (stability is great!  immunity is good) to do the surgery.     I don't have as much experience as others, recently diagnosed myself.   Sending hugs and positive thoughts your way
